title: Top takeaways from Due Diligence Live
text:
Due Diligence live: the highlight reel

What happens when you gather hundreds of Due Diligence subscribers and the biggest names in M&A, private equity, and corporate finance to discuss how they're confronting tumultuous markets, a dealmaking slowdown, and rising geopolitical tensions (to name just a few of the challenges on the horizon)?

A lot of bullishness on private equity. And some unfiltered commentary on Spacs, among other things.

Today's newsletter looks at the highlights from our full-day inaugural Due Diligence Live event. If you missed your chance to watch the sessions, you can still register to catch all of the action on-demand here.

1. The UK is up for sale

When Boris Johnson declared last year that the UK would make it “easier than ever for the world to benefit from what we have to offer”, he didn't expect overseas corporate raiders to take him so seriously. Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng's disastrous “mini” Budget has now sweetened the deal.

The plummeting value of sterling means that “everything in the UK is on sale”, said Blair Jacobson, co-head of European credit at Ares Management at DD Live.

Following deals like Clayton, Dubilier & Rice's purchase of Wm Morrison and the takeover of G4S, US dealmakers continue to ramp up their shopping spree in the UK.

The activity could help jump-start a comeback in M&A. “The first wave of M&A coming out of this is private equity-driven not corporate-driven,” Blair Effron, co-founder of  investment bank Centerview Partners, told DD.

DD's Kaye Wiggins and Antoine Gara have the full story.

2. The future of private capital

One big takeaway: dealmaking is likely to increasingly involve listed companies being taken private, said Ares' Jacobson. “The delisting trend will continue . . . we've been major beneficiaries of that trend.”

Deep-pocketed investors in the Middle East could also become an important source of cash as pension funds become more strapped for cash, he added.

Private equity is becoming increasingly liquid, said Further Global managing partner Olivier Sarkozy, giving it a “massive advantage” compared to public markets. Retail investors present “a massive untapped pool of capital that is going to come into the industry and propel it forward”, he added.

Watch the full panel here.

3. Rough days ahead for crypto and Spacs

“There is no way a government could function if it cannot tax its population . . . if crypto ever became sufficiently embedded it would become illegal,” Sarkozy told DD.

The financier also didn't hold back about Wall Street's fleeting love affair with Spacs. “The Spac market was a joke in my view. I hope I am not offending anybody.” 

https://twitter.com/ftlive/status/1580197243469983744

“Having been on the front end of a number of crypto restructurings . . . it is very difficult to see and value what they are worth,” said Latham & Watkins global head of private capital Yen Sum, adding that she believes the crypto asset class will see more liquidations.

4. ESG is in need of a refresh

The recent backlash surrounding companies' environmental, social and governance rhetoric was warranted, said Desiree Fixler, chair of VentureESG and former DWS executive whose whistleblower allegations on greenwashing prompted a police investigation into the German asset manager.

“I am actually very bullish on sustainable investments today,” she told DD's Ortenca Aliaj. “There was a green asset bubble . . . COP26 was a vanity project, whereas today you have to get real.” 

The consensus overall is that meaningful change won't be possible without co-operation between the public and private sectors. “The narrative that the private sector can solve this is absolutely nonsensical,” said Tariq Fancy, BlackRock's former head of sustainable investing.

5. The rise of shareholder activism

From its (so far unsuccessful) campaign at Richemont to taking on GSK, Glencore and Danone, Bluebell Capital Partners has risen to become a feared activist despite its small size.

The London-based fund's co-founder and co-investment chief Marco Taricco told DD that working constructively with company boards has resulted in a more profitable era of activism. “I would argue that private equity does exactly what we do — just in private markets.”

“There is a misconception that the influence over a company is tied to the amount of shares we own,” added Clearway Capital founder Gianluca Ferrari.

6. The ethics of short selling are debatable

Short sellers have had their fair share of criticism, from some blaming hedge funds for Deliveroo's ill-received listing, aka “the worst IPO in London's history” to the GameStop saga.

But should they be required to disclose their short positions? Here's a thought-provoking debate between Safkhet Capital Management founder and chief investment officer Fahmi Quadir and the FT's Dan McCrum on the subject.

7. There's a new regime for M&A antitrust

US Department of Justice antitrust chief Jonathan Kanter has made it no secret in recent months that private equity is on his radar as the industry's top players morph into powerful diversified conglomerates controlling vast swaths of the economy.

He goes into further detail in conversation with DD's Javier Espinoza.

“Private equity raises a range of considerations that can lead to antitrust issues, whether it's deal roll-ups, or interlocking board directors,” he said.

8. The finalists for the Chelsea Football Club takeover

More than 250 potential buyers had expressed interest in buying Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich's football club that was eventually sold to a consortium led by US financier Todd Boehly and California-based investment firm Clearlake Capital.

“We had some people representing various governments, we had crypto millionaires . . .” said Raine Group partner Colin Neville. Many of those suitors backed out due to “being uncomfortable with the geopolitics” and/or “the fact that there were no reps and warranties in the deal”, he added.

In the end, the decision boiled down to four finalists: Boehly and Clearlake, a group led by the Ricketts family (which owns the Chicago Cubs baseball team) and Citadel's Ken Griffin; a group led by Apollo's Josh Harris and Blackstone's David Blitzer; and a group led by Boston Celtics co-owner Steve Pagliuca, Neville told DD.

Watch the conversation here.

Job moves

  • Nader Haffar, the head of KPMG's Dubai business, is stepping down from the firm following a wave of allegations of nepotism, cronyism and partner discontent. Deals partner Anshul Gupta and former head of audit Emilio Pera are both expected to run in an upcoming election for the top job, said people familiar with the details.

  • Comcast has promoted chief financial officer Mike Cavanagh to the added role of president. He was previously co-chief executive of JPMorgan Chase's corporate and investment bank from 2012 to 2014.

  • Wells Fargo has hired Evercore's Sesh Raghavan as a managing director and its new head of power, utilities and renewables mergers and acquisitions.

  • Boutique investment bank William Blair has hired Dominic Emery as a managing director in London. He joins from Raymond James.

Smart reads

Danger zone Abrdn's £1.5bn acquisition of Interactive Investor has only dragged the ailing UK asset manager's share price down further. But the merger is only the tip of the iceberg, writes the FT's Cat Rutter Pooley.

Past their prime Long-short stockpickers used to carry a certain cache on Wall Street. But poor performance in the sector has dented the reputations of these once lauded hedge fund wizards, Bloomberg writes.

Made in India As global companies look to hedge their reliance on China, India has seized its opportunity to challenge Beijing's manufacturing dominance. Apple's new deal in New Delhi will serve as a critical test, writes the FT's John Reed.

And here's a smart listen: Trevor Milton and his electric vehicle start-up Nikola's Spac-fuelled rise to fame was swiftly shot down by a short-seller attack and subsequent fraud charges. The FT's Claire Bushey breaks down the saga as Milton's trial plays out in New York. Listen to the latest episode of Behind The Money here.

News round-up

UK insurers set to take on more company pension schemes (FT)

Carlyle weighs sale of Gabon oil and gas producer Assala 

Toshiba picks Tokyo fund group for potential ¥2.8tn buyout (Kyodo)

Blackstone forms insurance partnership with Resolution Life (Wall Street Journal)

British Steel auditor Mazars resigns over fee disagreement (FT)

MySale recommends shareholders to accept Mike Ashley's Frasers buyout offer (Reuters)

US law firm Boies Schiller plots London hires to meet ‘booming' demand for litigation work (Financial News)

Socionext: rare Japan chip listing comes just as sector peaks (Lex)

Blackstone converts Indian property to safe haven (Reuters Breakingviews)

Special report: women in business (FT)
